did.head: Descriptive Summary

repository.label: Repository
repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University

did.langmaterial: Material in English Chinese Japanese Spanish German French
did.physloc: For current information on the location of these materials, please consult the Library's online catalog.
did.abstract: McCann-Erickson, founded in 1930 from the merger of Alfred Erickson's and Harry McCann's agencies, is one of the largest advertising agencies in the United States. It is part of the Interpublic Group.

The McCann-Erickson Audiovisual Collection spans the 1980s and 1990s and consists of over 700 videocassette tapes of commercials for domestic, international and global advertising campaigns. Also included are tapes of competitor commercials; interviews with agency and industry leaders and marketing specialists; and presentations. Advertisers include: Apple computer; Bayer; Benson & Hedges; Buick; Calvin Klein; Camel (R.J. Reynolds); Coca-Cola; Del Monte; Exxon; Heineken; Kodak; Levi Strauss; Nestlé; Oxo; and Suntory. The bulk of materials consist of advertisements for campaigns in the United States, but Brazil, Japan and Germany are also heavily represented, as are commercials for Europe-wide campaigns. Acquired as part of the John W. Hartman Center for Sales, Advertising & Marketing History.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Researchers must register and agree to copyright and privacy laws before using this collection.
In addition, original audiovisual materials are closed to patron use. Technical Services staff need to produce use copies before contents can be accessed.
All or portions of this collection may be housed off-site in Duke University's Library Service Center. The library may require up to 48 hours to retrieve these materials for research use.
Please contact Research Services staff before visiting the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library to use this collection.

userestrict.head: Copyright Notice
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], McCann-Erickson Audiovisual Collection, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The McCann-Erickson Audiovisual Collection were received by the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library as a gift from William O'Barr in 1994.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processed by Richard Collier and Kirston Johnston, June 2008
Accession is described in this finding aid.
Descriptive sources and standards used to create this inventory: DACS, EAD, NCEAD guidelines, and local Style Guide.
This finding aid is NCEAD compliant.

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: The McCann-Erickson Audiovisual Collection spans the 1980s and 1990s and consists of over 700 videocassette tapes of commercials for domestic, international and global advertising campaigns. Also included are tapes of competitor commercials; interviews with agency and industry leaders and marketing specialists; and presentations. Advertisers include: Apple computer; Bayer; Benson & Hedges; Buick; Calvin Klein; Camel (R.J. Reynolds); Coca-Cola; Del Monte; Exxon; Heineken; Kodak; Levi Strauss; Nestlé; Oxo; and Suntory The bulk of materials consist of advertisements for campaigns in the United States, but Brazil, Japan and Germany are also heavily represented, as are commercials for Europe-wide campaigns.

arrangement.p: The collection is arranged into two Series: Original Videotapes; and Videotape Documentation. Original Videotapes list the videocassettes in numerical order, and provide contents listing where known; Videotape Documentation consists of tape contents lists removed from the cassette cases, along with notebooks containing notes on most of the videotapes--this information has been transcribed into the body of the finding aid in the Original Videotapes series; Original order was maintained. Tapes were sequentially numbered and are housed in numerical order. Some tapes were missing at the time of processing, a fact which is noted in the container list.

controlaccess.head: Subject Headings
controlaccess.p: These are searchable subject entries for this collection. Performing a search on these subjects in the Duke University Libraries online catalog will bring up other related research materials.

scopecontent.p: List of videotapes. Where known, detailed listings of videotape contents have been provided. Arranged in numerical order. Some numbered videotapes were missing when collection was received. These are noted in the container list.

111. Barry Day On Tape, Global Advertising: The Facts and the Fantasy. 1986. Umatic. NTSC. TRT: Unknown.

scopecontent.p: [Discussion about the prospect of global brands: find a global need; come up with a brand; then maybe you can have a global brand. Your product has to be used the same everywhere. Coke is used as the prime example. Analysis of cost, production, psychology. Global advertising has to be basic but not boring. Imagery crosses cultural boundaries. Cinzano's failure in the global market vs. Martini's success. Differences between global marketing and global brands.]

128. Humour in Advertising. 1977. Umatic. NTSC. TRT: Unknown.

scopecontent.p: [Barry Day commentary on humor in advertising. Unsuccessful attempts; movie/TV/musical stars--familiarity breeds instant comedy; parody of familiar movie/TV formats; nostalgia; using stereotypes (especially of foreigners) to generate humor; humor is based in reality--but exaggeration allows us to laugh at ourselves; simplified slice of life allows us to remain separate.]

did.unittitle: 206. Barry Day Interviews Judith Daniels for Women at Work Presentation. Undated. Umatic. NTSC. TRT: Unknown.

scopecontent.p: [See also Tapes 201, 207. New women stereotype--the business woman; household wife/bungling husband--less so now; women often still portrayed as gullible, needy of help; catering to women who work outside the home to the exclusion of the full-time homemaker; don't have to associate women with their jobs--it doesn't matter if they work or not; using the shopping center as an educational extension--no more fashion shows, women want information; time savers are very important for working women; don't have to polarize advertisements--glamor does not have to be in the office; men's reactions to the rising successes of women.]

did.unittitle: 207. Barry Day Interviews Kate Rand-Lloyd for Women at Work Presentation. Undated. Umatic. NTSC. TRT: Unknown.

scopecontent.p: [See also tapes 201, 206. Know your target audience. Working women: 80% are in dead end, low status jobs; 20% are career oriented, professional/managerial jobs, these latter are vocal about what they like/don't like, and enjoy androgynous advertising. What is the role of fantasy in career women advertising? The female dream is not the male dream in a dress. Advertising doesn't do any favors to housewives by perpetuating the fantasy of homemaking as wonderful and lasting forever. Many housewives will be headed back to the workforce, and they need to be prepared.]

scopecontent.p: [Idea of: stop, relax, break away. The More you love coffee, the longer you'll stay and visit. Image of men working--give bread they've baked to woman and daughter, then take a break to drink coffee; man seated at desk, woman brings him coffee--unclear if she is a secretary or colleague--she hands him coffee and they both drink; secretary hands coffee to boss--he drinks; two women relaxing at home over coffee. Coffee exists before commercial starts--no scenes of people actually making coffee.]

388. Ad Video Journal--Issue #8; Advertising Cars: Detroit v. Japan. Undated. Umatic. NTSC. TRT: 35:00

scopecontent.p: [See also Tape 389. With the end of the VRA (Voluntary Restriction Act) on Japanese import cars, the Japanese cars started to be a major portion of the market. Discussion on how Ford dealt with the influx of Japan and what they did with their advertising. Taking on Toyota, Nissan, Honda. Talk about Honda strategy over the last few years--simple message. Nissan strategy: stress quality. Toyota strategy: what you want. Japanese imports got the jump on sports cars, but then moved on to more standard cars as well. Japanese cars began to look American. The current battle is the very new models.]

394. Exxon--Esso Tiger Presentation Reel With Barry Day (In Colour). 1982. Umatic. NTSC. TRT: 18:00

scopecontent.p: [Teh lasting icon of the Esso Tiger--all incarnations; it has lasted because it is in the heart and mind of the consumer; it covers the whole spectrum of the product; how flexible is the tiger as an advertising vehicle? could it step outside the area of playful salesmanship? Consistency of use has made the tiger a very successful icon and symbol; it works in all media; the Esso Tiger is beautiful, powerful and serious--it is not urbane, cuddly, a people tiger, or one of a pair; cartoon image only for selling gas, the live tiger is the true corporate image.]

481. The Japanese Economy Now. Undated. Umatic. NTSC. TRT: Unknown.

scopecontent.p: [Ultramodern industrial facilities are the best in the world, but they rely heavily on imported energy and raw materials. Their rapid growth has made them #2 in the world, but they cannot keep this up. They have two problems they must solve: a recession at home; and imbalance with trade abroad--far more exports than imports. The rapid growth of teh '70s was very short-lived. Japan must now fit in with a long-term low-growth process.]

scopecontent.p: [Introduction by Barry Day. Presentation covering all areas of showing food in an advertising campaign. Consumer and housewife responses to different photo moments for fresh and prepared foods. What should we ask of the home economist? How do we make food look hot? How real should the food be? How important is the choice of photographer or film maker? How important is the recipe? How do you get good reproduction in print? How can we show food in black and white? How can we best exploit food on film?]

531. Jif Guidelines. Undated. Umatic. NTSC. TRT: Unknown.

scopecontent.p: [CIF/JIF advertising analysis. International use of French custodian advertising. Product originated in France, but has expanded to 18 countries. Despiet a brand policy document, a video guidelines tape, and written guidelines, the brand's advertising execution has varied considerably in content and quality. This tape is to analyze the basic elements of the French advertising material, on a frame by frame basis, using the guidelines documents. See how it's been handled in receiver countries, and then draw conclusions.]

585. Light Camera Politics, Richard Reives. 1980. Umatic. NTSC. TRT: Unknown.

scopecontent.p: [An ABC News closeup on political coverage on television. Heavy use of ABC, NBC, CBS 1980 Presidential election coverage. Richard Reeves reports on his 20 years experience in political coverage, adnhow television has changed the political process, from the beginning of new coverage in the late '50s to the modern coverage of today. National leaders used to control everything, but television took that away. Television changed government during Watergate, but after that, politics changed to suit television.]

661. Ritz; Goodyear; Esso. 1986. Umatic. NTSC. TRT: Unknown.

scopecontent.p: [Discussion of R.J. Reynolds/Nabisco merger and how Nabisco was then subject to the RJR transnational marketing/advertising scheme. The marketing strategy behind expanding Ritz's market including: The Wizard of Ritz; The Ritz Baker; The Magician; and The Professor. Alternate strategies are also covered: Irresistible Taste; Nature's Gold; and Ritz It Up. Goodyear International Advertising: The strategy had to be simple and all-encompassing, an emotional evocation--discusison about different strategies behind Goodyear, Take Me Home. The people approach; the panorama approach. Esso: Several projects that the Esso campaign is dealing with. The Tiger Project--the future use of the tiger. The Brazilian campaign--they want to abolish the old advertising and use something completely new.]

684. Group of Brands Acceptability. 1984. Umatic. NTSC. TRT: 39:00

scopecontent.p: [Chuck Mittelstadt, Manager of CAS, gives a speech on the topic of multiple brands that are seen as equals in performance. Consumers see very little difference between brands for any products. They are all acceptable. Lowest price is usually the determining factor. With this idea in mind, what can brands do to draw the consumer other than discount prices? --Rebuild brand uniqueness through product and package improvements; consumer promotions other than off-price (such as contests, sweepstakes, etc.); downprice into the economy tier; rebuild brand uniqueness with fresh and persuasive advertising.]

did.unittitle: 685. Comfort Guidelines. Undated. Umatic. NTSC. TRT: Unknown.

scopecontent.p: [A presentation on the recommended advertising approach for countries who have just launched or are planning to launch Comfort fabric softener. Campaigns center aroung three ideas: explain softness benefit; add emotional appeal; add fresh smell. Some countries need educational commercials to explain why the product is beneficial and sometimes what the product is in the first place. Examples of commercials and clips from several countries are used to illustrate.]
